I'm pretty sure that you are thinking about the channeled scablands of Washington and Oregon. They were caused when an ice damn at Lake Missoula (in Montana) broke and allowed the water to run to the Pacific. Study has shown that there were several occurrences of this event as the damn broke, reformed and broke again.
 
 The scablands are in effect the falsification of the method of formation of the Grand Canyon that is claimed by creationists. Creationists claim an event like that of Lake Missoula and the channelled scablands carved out the Grand Canyon. Creationists have invented a lake that they claim drained through and carved out the Grand Canyon. However, the landscape around the Grand Canyon doesn't resemble the channelled scablands, which means that it wasn't a massive damn burst.
 
 Further, huge damn bursts don't produce structures like Horseshoe Bend in the Colorado River just below Page, AZ. These structures are produced by slow moving water flowing over relatively flat land until they become entrenched. There are lots of meanders in the course of the Grand Canyon.

I remember being fascinated as a school kid about Lake Agassiz, it being a part of Minnesota and thus having a special connection with me. I've had a chance to visit the area around Red Lake, which is a remnant of that mighty prehistoric lake. 
 
 But I had never heard of Glacial Lake Missoula, and the cataclysmic event that shaped so much of the Northwest. I googled around a bit and enjoyed taking the virtual tour of the area affected by the lake and its runoff.
 
 It's too bad Creationists can't enjoy the wonder of this natural event. It's so much more satisfying to consider that a ice dam broke and caused the ensuing flood rather than contemplating a petulant god having a temper tantrum. Understanding how giant boulders caught a ride on ice floes and hitched a ride over great distances from their origin is more fascinating than trying to imagine two penguins waddling thousands of miles to catch a ride on a stupid wooden boat. Channeled scablands are better appreciated, IMO, as a result of rushing water and gravity than supposing a god carved it with his holy finger.
 
 In short, if you want to be filled with awe, take your superstitious blinders off.
